content:
That's a great point about focus! When you're reading a physical book, you're more likely to be fully engaged with the story, which can indeed help with retention and recall. Audiobooks, on the other hand, can be more prone to distraction, especially if you're multitasking.

However, it's wonderful that you're able to enjoy the story just as much either way. That's the most important thing, right? Being able to immerse yourself in a good story and connect with the characters and plot.

It's also interesting that you bring up focus, because some research suggests that audiobooks can actually be more engaging for certain people, especially those who are auditory learners or have trouble focusing on written text. So, it really does come down to personal preference and what works best for each individual.

Now, I'm curious - have you ever found yourself switching between formats for the same book? For example, starting with an audiobook and then switching to a physical copy, or vice versa?
